title.narrative: Nordic Trust Fund World bank human rights 2014-2018

description.narrative:
Insatsen syftar till att stärka Världsbankens arbete med mänskliga rättigheter (MR), framförallt internt och i form av kapacitetsstärkande åtgärder inom banken, men också externa MR-aktiviteter som ingår i WBs olika projekt. Syftet är således att bidra med kunskap om mänskliga rättigheter och hur det relaterar till bankens kärnverksamhet för att minska fattigdom och bidra med ekonomisk tillväxt. NTF tillkom efter flera år av förhandlingar där Sverige tillsammans med övriga nordiska länder var mycket aktiv. Sverige har givit stöd till NTF sedan 2008. 2009 övergick ansvaret för NTF till Sida från UD. NTF´s verksamhet startades 2009 och har hittills bidragit till goda resultat och skapat en gedigen plattform och kunskapsbas inom banken kring mänskliga rättigheter. Förutom intern utbildning av personal inom banken i MR så riktas 85% av budgeten till projekt i fält där MR perspektivet integreras och tas hänsyn till i både design och implementering av projekten. Många av de projekt som genomförts i fält har fortsatt efter projektperioden med egna resurser - vilket indikerar att det finns ett upplevt mervärde från bankens personal i fält.
Sammanfattningsvis bedöms NTF att har på relativt kort tid lyckats skapa ett intresse för mänskliga rättigheter inom banken och kunnat visa på kopplingar hur det hänger ihop med bankens mandat, fattigdomsbekämpning och utveckling.

The contribution is aimed at strengthening the World Bank's work on human rights, primarly internally and in terms of capacity strengthening measures within the bank, but also externally by including human rights perspectives into WB projects and activities. The aim is thus to contribute with knowledge about human rights and how it relates to the Bank's core business in order to reduce poverty and to contribute to economic growth.
NTF was founded after several years of negotiations in which Sweden together with the other Nordic countries were very active. Sweden has supported NTF since 2008. In 2009 the responsibility for the NTF was transferred from the Foreign Ministry to Sida. NTF activities started in 2009 and has so far contributed to concreate results and created a solid platform and knowledge base within the Bank about human rights. In addition to internal training of personnel within the Bank in human rights about 85% of the budget is directed to projects at country level. Many of the projects implemented in the field has continued after the project period with own resources-which indicates that there is a perceived added value of these projects in the Banks architecture

The objective of the Nordic Trust Fund (NTF) managed by the World Bank (WB) was to help the WB develop "an informed view of how human rights relate to its analytical activities and operations". It did so through two programs: (i) the grant program under which task teams across the World Bank Group (WBG) received financial and technical support to explore and operationalize human rights in their projects or programs; and (ii) the knowledge and partnership program which provided training and capacity building to WB staff to familiarize them with human rights initiatives in their sectors of work and to incorporate human rights standards and principles in their work, and builds partnerships with relevant external stakeholders.

description.narrative: Below a few examples of results summarised: Right to Childhood: Middle East With the support of the NTF and in collaboration with Save the Children and the University of Gothenburg, Sweden, a report was produced on rights-based programming for children in conflict-affected areas in the Middle East. The report examined the effectiveness of child-rights programming. It found that a child rights based programming improved security, helped strengthen the relationship between the community and the state, and eased tension between different groups through training of children and youth in peaceful participation. The study created clear recommendations for governments, organizations, and donors. Transitional justice in Colombia Colombia suffered through a half-century of armed conflict. The Colombian government and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) signed a historic agreement in 2016 and the country began the slow, precarious transition towards peace. The NTF began to work with Colombia in 2010 and supported six grants, more than any other nation. Four focused on peace building and two explored the right to health. One of the peace-building grants assisted with a mobile victims’ unit, which traveled to remote municipalities to record victim’s statements, provide psychological and legal counseling, inform victims of their rights, and explain the reparation process for their land. The unit reached more than 60,000 people by 2016, although NTF’s evaluation showed the information was too technical and many victims didn’t understand their rights. This is an important lesson learnt. The Colombian government changed it strategy based on this guidance. Another grant helped the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) and the WB design a program that aimed to improve communication methods, through tools such as infographics and text messages, to better connect with victims. This led to the creation of a toolkit about communicating rights in post-conflict situations, which has become an important resource for Colombia and the WB. Human Rights Recognized: Environment and Social Framework The NTF awarded a grant to develop guidance on the principle of non-discrimination and funded consultation workshops, actions that played a role in the inclusion of human rights language in the WB 2018 Environmental and Social Framework. The framework enables the WB and partner countries to better manage the environmental and social risks of projects and includes human rights principles such as transparency, accountability, participation and non-discrimination.
